Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Neural Mechanisms Underlying Self-Recognition in Non-human Primates
Award.AbstractNarration:
Self-awareness is the capacity to comprehend that one exists as an individual, separate from others and the environment. It is the highest cognitive function and, interestingly, the least understood. Self-recognition in front of a mirror has been used as an indicator of self-awareness in animals and young humans because they cannot articulate what they perceive and experience.

Aside from humans, who start to recognize themselves in the mirror at about 18 months of age, mirror self-recognition has only been shown in species that cannot be used for physiological studies of the function of the nervous system, i.e., in primates chimpanzees and orangutans. Recently, however, we have shown that rhesus monkeys, the animal model closest to humans available for electrophysiological studies, are indeed able to recognize themselves in the mirror despite failing the most traditional mirror self-recognition test, the mark test (Rajala et al. 2010). This finding has cleared the way for the investigation of the neural mechanisms underlying self-awareness. The similarity of the monkey brain with the human will allow us to draw important parallels between the two species. The studies will use a combination of behavioral (oculomotor) and physiological techniques (single unit recordings from higher order areas of the cerebral cortex) in awake, behaving rhesus monkeys. This approach is expected to reveal the connection between the subjects' psychophysical reports of self-awareness and the underlying neural substrate.

The broader impacts of the project will include educational and training components from elementary to graduate school levels. Presentations about the structure and function of the nervous system will be given at elementary and high-school levels, and undergraduate and graduate students will be trained in science through research opportunities in the laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this EAGER project was to study the neural mechanisms underlying self-awareness. This is the highest order and least understood of cognitive functions.  It has been typically measured with visual self-recognition in front of a mirror.  

 Until recently, mirror self-recognition had been demonstrated in species that were not available for direct studies of the function of the nervous system, such as chimpanzees and orangutans. The demonstration by this laboratory that macaque monkeys are able to recognize themselves in the mirror opened up a completely new avenue for investigating how self-awareness is made possible by the nervous system of primates.

 Accordingly, an EAGER award was awarded vy the NSF to take advantage of this opportunity.  Although the award originally provided funding for two years, we received funding only for the first year. During this time, we developed this animal model into a suitable preparation for laboratory studies. Specifically, we focused our efforts on three methodologies: (1) behavioral using both mirrors that distorted the normal view of the subject’s face and videos with different time delays and distorsions; (2) functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) aimed at identifying the areas of the primate brain responsible for processing information underlying self-recognition and self-awareness; (3) electrophysiological recordings from the prefrontal cortex, and area of the brain thought to be involved in self-awareness.

The data obtained during this initial year are promising, albeit very preliminary, and are currently being used for grant applications to obtain the necessary funds to complete the studies. We are optimistic that our efforts will produce the additional funds necessary to complete the proposed studies, and that we will be able to shed much needed light on the neural mechanisms underlying our ability to be self-aware.
